div.head: A. Decay of emotions and wages
div.p: According to H2b we expect emotions and changes in wage to be more pronounced at the beginning of the experiment than at the end. Figure 11 provides an overview. arousal dominance valence wage 1 2 3 1 2 3 1 2 3 2 3 0.2 0.4

The vertical axis shows for emotion dimensions the change in emotion |M i,m,t -M i,m,t-1 | and for the wage the change in the wage |W i,t -W i,t-1 |. Since we elicit emotions four times during the experiment, we can report three changes. Since wages are paid only three times, we report only for two rounds changes of the wage. Indeed, changes in arousal and dominance seem to decrease during the experiment. Changes in valence and wage seem to increase over time.

div.head: B. Time: Decay of emotions and wages
div.p: According to H2b we also expect the effect of early emotions to be maintained over time (low decay rate). To investigate this hypothesis, we estimate the effect of emotions in the first and in the second round both on changes in wages in the third round. We estimate

where the emotion m of participant i at time t is M i,m,t and the lag l ∈ {1, 2} (i.e. one or two period lag). We use both OLS and an IV estimator with feedback as an instrument for the regressor. Figure 12 shows estimation results.

Valence is the only emotion which shows a significant effect from the second round to wages in the third round. We do find an impact of valence on decay. The effect from the first round to wages in the third round is clearly smaller. 2An overview of these results is shown in Figure 4. Odds are provided in Figure 5. An overview of these results is shown in Figure 8. Odds are provided in Figure 9. • Assuming you unlocked the reward and paid the counter €2, how much will you get? (€7, €5, €3)

div.head: F.1. No controls
div.p: • Assuming you unlocked the reward and paid the counter €4, how much will you get? (€7, €5, €3)
• Which of the 3 times you have done calculations will be taken into account? (One, randomly selected, All, The first time)

div.head: G.3. Control questions 2
div.p: • What is your ID in this experiment? Please write in uppercase letters. If you are unsure of your ID, write it down as best you can. If it is not correct, we will then remind you of your actual ID. • Choose the correct option: (Choices: Most counters are already satisfied with 2€ or more, Most counters are only satisfied with 4€ or more)

div.head: G.4. Decisions in each period
div.p: • Pay: (Currency) What the participant pays counters, shown as a slider from 0 to 7 with no preset, in steps of 0.1. Instructions, page 2 of 10
The task of the counters: Counters must count the number of dots in a series of 5 dotted lines. They do this 3 times, once for each of the calculators they are working with. Example:
• You see ……………. The correct number of dots is 16
• You see ……… The correct number of dots is 9
• You see ……….. The correct number of dots is 11
• You see …. The correct number of dots is 4
• You see …….. The correct number of dots is 8
The counters have already done their part so that you as a calculator can do the second part of the work.

div.head: Instructions, page 3 of 10
div.p: Your task as a calculator: You use the numbers reported by counters to perform a calculation. This calculation includes addition (+), subtraction (-), multiplication (*) and division (/). You do this 3 times, once for each of the counters you are working with.
Example: The counter reports 10, 2, 15, 10, 7. You may then need to perform a calculation such as 10-2*15/10+7 or similar calculations with these numbers.

div.head: Instructions, page 4 of 10
div.p: If neither you nor the counter make a mistake, you will find the hidden number and the €7.00 reward will be unlocked. The €7.00 will be paid to you. You then decide what portion of the €7.00 reward you want to pay to the counter. If you don't find the hidden number, the reward will not be unlocked and neither you nor the counter will get paid. This happens when the counter does not count the number of dots correctly or you do not do the calculation correctly.

div.head: Instructions, page 5 of 10
div.p: Example 1: Suppose the counter says 10, 2, 15, 10, 8. Your calculation is then 10-2*15/10+7. The correct answer is 14, the hidden number. However, if you report 13, neither of you will get anything. This is the case even though the counter reported the numbers correctly to you.

Example 2: Suppose the correct numbers are 10, 2, 15, 10, 8. However, the counter reports 9, 2, 15, 10, 8. You calculate 9-2*15/10+7 and report 13. Your calculation is correct, but this is not the hidden number (14), so neither of you gets anything. This happens even though you have done your calculation correctly, because you have received the wrong numbers from the counter.

div.head: Control questions
div.p: We will now ask you 4 control questions to check if you have been paying attention before we begin. The experiment begins when you have answered all 4 questions correctly. (See subsection G.3)
We come to the actual experiment
We now come to the part of the experiment where you do calculations and decide how much you want to pay each counter. Before we do this, we want to know how you feel right now using SAM.
How sad or happy do you feel?
How calm or excited do you feel?
How powerless or powerful do you feel?

div.head: Your decision
div.p: Counter 1 counted the following numbers: 9, 3, 7, 5, 6. Based on these numbers, please perform the following calculation: 9 * 3 -(7 + 5) / 6 Result: (number inputs)
Hint: The answer is an integer. How much would you like to pay Counter 1 if successful? Click on the blue bar to display the slider.
Reminder: You are known as PUCU in this experiment. Most counters only give positive feedback if you give them€4.00 or more. We will not show you any feedback from Counter 1 about what you paid them.

div.head: Results
div.p: You are known as PUCU in this experiment. You have decided to pay Counter 1 €4.90 (This is for the treatment without feedback. In treatment with feedback they see the feedback (thumb up or down) and in the treatment without feedback they are reminded this feedback will be made public).
How do you feel about this? (Same elicitation of emotions as before.) (Those two steps of decision and result are repeated over three rounds.)

div.head: Feedback
div.p: You have now made all your payment decisions. Finally, we would like to know how you judge your behavior in this experiment from a moral point of view (See subsection G.5).

div.head: Questionnaire, page 1 of 8
div.p: Now that the experiment is over, we will ask you a series of questions about yourself. You will then be paid. These questions are divided into 8 pages, with 5 to 10 questions on each page. For participating in this survey you will receive an additional €2.00. Please do your best to answer each question carefully and truthfully. The answers to these questions are important to evaluate the results of this experiment.

div.head: Questionnaire, page 2 of 8
div.p: On this page we want to learn about you (See subsection G.6).

div.head: Questionnaire, pages 3 to 7 of 8
div.p: (See subsection G.7).

div.head: Questionnaire, page 8 of 8
div.p: (See subsection G.8).

div.head: End of the experiment
div.p: The experiment is now over. Thank you for your participation! Your decision in Round 1 was randomly selected for payment. In this round, your answer was wrong. You calculated 18, but the hidden number was 25. Therefore, you will not receive the €7.00 reward. You will only receive €3.00 + €2.00 = €5.00 as compensation for participating in this experiment. You can contact us at (email) if you have not received this payout within the next 30 days.

div.head: Instructions, page 3 of 7
div.p: The task of calculators: Calculators use the numbers you provide to perform a calculation. This calculation includes addition (+), subtraction (-), multiplication (*) and division (/). Calculators do this 3 times, once for each of the counters they are working with.

div.head: Example:
div.p: You report counting 10, 2, 15, 10 and 7 dots. The calculator may then need to perform a calculation such as 10-2*15/10+7 or similar calculations on these numbers.

div.head: Instructions, page 4 of 7
div.p: If neither you nor the calculator make a mistake, the calculator will find the hidden number and the reward €7.00 will be unlocked. The €7.00 is paid to the calculator. The calculator then decides what share of the €7.00 you will receive. If the calculator does not find the hidden number, the reward will not be unlocked and neither you nor the calculator will be paid. This happens when you do not count the number of dots correctly or the calculator does not perform the calculation correctly.

div.head: Instructions, page 5 of 7
div.p: Example 1: Suppose you report 10, 2, 15, 10, 8 and the calculator has to calculate 10-2*15/10+7. The correct answer is 14, the hidden number. However, if the calculator says 13, neither of you will get anything. This happens even though you entered the numbers correctly.

Example 2: Suppose the correct numbers are 10, 2, 15, 10, 8, but you report 9, 2, 15, 10, 8. The calculator calculates 9-2*15/10+7 and reports 13. However, this is not the hidden number (14), so neither of you gets anything. This happens even though the calculator performed the calculation correctly, because you reported the wrong numbers.

div.head: Instructions, page 6 of 7
div.p: At the end of the experiment, one of the 3 calculators you worked with will be randomly selected. Your payment depends on whether the hidden number was found in this round and how much the calculator pays you in this round. Any of the 3 calculators you are working with can be selected. Therefore, count the dots carefully each time!

div.head: Instructions, page 7 of 7
div.p: To check whether you have been paying attention, we will ask you 4 control questions before we begin. The experiment begins when you have answered all 4 questions correctly.
What is your job? (I have to count dots on 5 lines, I have to calculate with 5 numbers) Suppose you unlocked the reward and the calculator pays you €2, how much does the calculator get? (7€, 5€, 3€)
Suppose you unlocked the reward and the calculator pays you €4, how much does the calculator get? (7€, 5€, 3€)

div.head: Count 1
div.p: We now ask you to count for calculator 1: 1) ……… How many dots does row 1 have? 2) … How many dots does row 2 have? 3) ……. How many dots does row 3 have? 4) ….. How many dots does row 4 have? 5) …… How many dots does row 5 have? (This is presented three times)

div.head: Feedback
div.p: Now tell us what feedback we should give the calculators based on how much they pay you. Depending on what they pay you and your feedback decision, the calculators will either receive: -a positive feedback (green signal with a thumb up): or -a negative feedback (red signal with a thumb down):

We think it makes sense to give positive feedback as long as the calculator pays you something. This is because some of them may decide not to pay you anything. Therefore, it makes sense to give good feedback to those who pay something.
